analytic.title: Environmental and historical determinants of fern richness across spatial grains

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Aim
div.p: To disentangle the hierarchy of historical and environmental factors determining fern richness at regional and plot scale.

div.head: Location
div.p: Global.

div.head: Time Period
div.p: Present.

div.head: Major Taxa studied
div.p: Ferns and lycophytes (together called "ferns").

div.head: Methods
div.p: We collated a global dataset of nearly 83,000 vegetation plots of similar area size (300-500m 2 ) in which all fern species were counted. For the regional grain size, we constructed a global fern richness model based on environment-richness relationships obtained from 1243 regional floras in combination with climatic, topographical, and biogeographical predictors. Environmental and historical/biogeographical determinants of species richness per plot were assessed at two spatial resolutions: regional grain size (7666 km 2 ) and local grain size (4 km 2 ). We used structural equation modelling to identify the direct and indirect effects of these factors on fern species richness per plot worldwide.

div.head: Results
div.p: Plot fern richness showed a hump-shaped relationship with regional richness. The comparison of different structural equation models revealed that botanical realm as a summary variable for historical processes was an important direct predictor of regional richness, but not of plot richness. Models allowing a link between regional (large grain size) environment and plot richness performed better than models without this link.

div.head: Main Conclusions
div.p: Plot fern richness increases with regional richness until a saturation point is reached, after which plot richness decreases despite increasing regional richness, possibly reflecting species interactions. Historical determinants do not affect plot fern richness directly but indirectly through the mediating effect of regional richness being strongly determined by biogeographical processes. Regional environment is an important determinant of plot richness, and cannot be replaced by including regional richness.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: One of the most fundamental questions in plant ecology and biogeography asks which processes determine species richness patterns at different spatial scales (i.e. extents and resolutions/grain sizes). Regional and local species richness are interlinked through a hierarchy of historical, environmental and biotic processes but their relative influences on both regional and local richness remain unknown (Cornell & Lawton, 1992). Even though the importance of scale in ecological analyses has been commonly acknowledged since the 1950s (e.g. Hutchinson, 1953;Whittaker, 1977;Ricklefs, 1987;Levin, 1992;Rahbek, 2005;Chase et al., 2019), detailed global analyses of the processes influencing biodiversity patterns at different spatial scales have long been hindered by lack of data and appropriate statistical methods (Beck et al., 2012). Today, advanced statistical methods (e.g. Keil & Chase, 2018) and comprehensive datasets (e.g. Bruelheide et al., 2018) at different spatial scales have become available, allowing the study of macroecological patterns across scales for many organism groups;.

Ferns and lycophytes (hereafter together referred to as "ferns") have a global distribution, and with around 10,500 and 1350 currently accepted species, respectively (PPG1, 2016), make up the second and third largest vascular plant lineages on Earth after angiosperms (Smith, 1972). With an estimated age of about 400 Myr, ferns are an exceptionally old group of vascular plants that -together with gymnosperms -dominated terrestrial vegetation before the rise of the angiosperms (Niklas, Tiffney & Knoll, 1983). Large portions of their extant diversity, however, are of recent origin and their diversification happened "in the shadow of angiosperms" (Schneider et al., 2004), commonly as understorey or epiphytic species in the newly developing angiosperm forests (Schuettpelz & Pryer, 2009).

Over the last three decades, several studies have focussed on the spatial distribution of fern diversity at different spatial resolutions and extents: At a global extent, Kreft, Jetz, Mutke & Barthlott (2010) found regional fern species richness (i.e. the number of species occurring in regions with an extent of hundreds to thousands of square kilometres) to be strongly and positively related to water-energy variables such as potential evapotranspiration and precipitation. They also found a strong positive relationship with geographical habitat heterogeneity, whereas the total surface area of the focal region only had moderate effects.

Together, their results confirmed a strong latitudinal gradient in fern species richness, which peaked in tropical regions, especially in tropical mountains. Beyond effects of contemporary environment, significant differences between biogeographical realms (e.g. tropical Africa being less diverse than other tropical regions), pointed to a strong role of biogeographical and historical processes. This pattern is also known from other plant groups, such as palms (Couvreur & Baker, 2013) or vascular plants in general (Kreft & Jetz, 2007). Also for small grain sizes of typically a few hundred square metres, numerous studies have shown that fern diversity typically peaks in tropical regions and that especially the midelevations along elevational gradients are particularly species-rich (e.g. Salazar et al., 2015;Kessler, Kluge, Hemp & Ohlemüller, 2011, and references therein). For instance, in a comparison of 20 elevational gradients on different continents, Kessler et al. (2011) found that the fern species richness correlated most strongly with climatic variables, mainly heat-related water deficiency at low elevations and predictors related to low temperatures that limit diversity at high elevations. The authors compare the elevational gradient to the latitudinal gradient in that temperatures decline towards higher elevations/latitudes. They also noted differences in local species richness among continents. Going one step further, Karger et al. (2011) compared five elevational transects within the tropics and found that after the effect of area of the representative elevational belt was accounted for, local and regional richness patterns were almost identical, suggesting that they are either driven by the same factors or that local richness equals a certain subset of regional richness and is directly driven by the size of the regional species pool. In contrast to these results, Karger et al. (2014) found that on islands of different sizes in the Indo-Malayan archipelago, local species richness was driven by local environmental conditions and not by differences in regional (island-wide) species richness, suggesting that the two are independent. However, Tuomisto, Zuquim & Cárdenas (2014) found that local fern species richness in Amazonian rain forests increased with soil nutrient concentration, and that this was paralleled by an increase in the total number of species (substrate-specific species pool size).

In a broader context, it has been argued that the environment can strongly limit the number of locally co-occurring species numbers, thus leading to local saturation in that increases of regional species richness will not be reflected at the local scale (Srivastava, 1999;Olivares, Karger & Kessler 2018). Nevertheless, the cross-scale relationships between regional and local fern richness and their drivers remain puzzling. As mentioned above, environmental predictors at different resolutions have been discussed as underlying causes, but whether factors at larger grain size only act on regional richness or also on local/plot richness remains widely untested. Similarly, it has been shown that historical factors are correlated with both regional and local species richness. But it is unclear whether these factors, which typically act at large spatial extents and over long time periods, do not only influence regional richness but may also have more local effects. To understand the causal relationships, we analysed the hierarchical structure of environmental and biogeographical determinants of fern species richness at two resolutions, "regional" (at a large grain size of 7666 km 2 ) and "local" (i.e. at a fine grain size resolution of 4 km 2 ) on regional (7666 km 2 ) and plot fern richness (300-500 m 2 ). We combined a large dataset of almost 83,000 vegetation plots with a model of regional fern richness, which fills in gaps of unknown regional species richness in some areas, and makes regional richness comparable independently of age and completeness of the input species lists. Using structural equation modelling, we tried to answer the following main questions: Q1: How do plot and regional fern richness relate to each other on a global scale? Can we observe saturation? Q2: Do historical factors, summarised in biogeographical/botanical realms, act on regional and plot fern richness or is only regional richness impacted, which in turn shapes plot richness? Q3: Do regional environmental conditions (at large grain size) impact regional and plot fern richness or only regional, which in turn impacts plot richness?

div.head: Regional fern richness data
div.p: In order to bridge differences in completeness, age, and overall availability between regional species lists of protected areas, regions, states or countries, we built a model of regional fern species richness. For this, we extracted species presence information on 1243 geographic entities from the Global Inventory of Floras and Traits database (GIFT; Weigelt, König & Kreft, 2019). All originally available entities were filtered for those mentioning fern species numbers, including true absences. Entities with less than five occurring fern species were double checked to be certain that false underrepresentation is avoided. When an entity overlapped with another one by more than 10%, the larger one was excluded from analyses. Environmental predictor variables were extracted from 30-arc second resolution environmental raster layers and summarised across the extent of each geographic entity (as mean, median, 75% quantile or 95% quantile; the best fitting summary was chosen for each predictor). Botanical continent (continental scheme level 1 of the Taxonomic Database Working Group (Brummitt, 2001) was additionally included as a substitute variable of not directly measurable historical influences, which might influence vegetation patterns differently across biogeographical realms until today. Global coverage ranged from a minimum of 30 entities in the Antartic realm to a maximum of 315 in South America. In order to assess regional diversity independently from the covered geographical extent of the regional entity, we used generalised linear models (GLMs, with Poisson distribution) to ascertain environment-richness relationships and project regional fern richness on a hexagon equal area grid with a grid cell size of 7666 km 2 (Barnes, 2017). Based on what is known about determinants of global fern richness (Kreft et al., 2010), we tested environmental predictors (Supp. Table 1) variables from for the models and the best performing ones were included in the final model.

div.head: Plot richness data
div.p: To analyse plot fern richness, we collated a global dataset of almost 83,000 vegetation plots ranging in size between 300 m 2 and 500 m 2 from the sPlot consortium (Bruelheide et al., 2018), species lists from ground vegetation surveys carried out on Level II plots of the Europewide forest monitoring programme ICP Forests (http://www.icp-forests.net, Ferretti & Fischer, 2013;Canullo, Starlinger, Granke, Fischer & Aamlid, 2016), and published and unpublished data from fern inventories carried out by a research network on fern diversity (e.g. Kessler et al., 2011;Karger et al., 2014;Zuquim et al., 2014;Tuomisto et al., 2014;Hernández-Rojas et al., 2018; see Figure 1 for plot distribution and Supp. Table 2 for full plot list). For the sPlot data (sPlot version 1.2, 20 th April 2018), the following filters applied: at least one fern species occurring, explicit geographical coordinates with a location uncertainty below 5,000 m and an area size between 300 m 2 and 500 m 2 . ICP Forest data included Level II ground vegetation data between the years 1994 and 2012, accessed in October 2016. Plots that were sampled repeatedly throughout this time frame were kept, but never selected within the same run of the statistical analyses (see details below). For the Amazon plots that originally only included terrestrials and hemi-epiphytes up to 2 m height, species numbers were increased by 10% and rounded to the next full number in agreement with the responsible specialists. Although the data were collected in the scope of many different projects, they all included complete species inventories of fern and lycophyte species. Some of them applied thresholds to juvenile species, but as we are dealing with species presence numbers instead of abundance, we consider these differences to be negligible in comparison to the differences caused by environmental conditions.

Environmental data for each plot were extracted on a 2x2 km 2 scale due to potential GPS inaccuracies. Additionally, we extracted the number of predicted regional fern species from the regional model for the polygon in which each plot was located. Soil properties were not included due to the small-scale variation in soils in many regions of the Earth and the fact that soil samples from the plots were only available for a very small number of plots.

Statistical analyses
div.p: All spatial and statistical analyses were carried out in the programming environment R (version 3.5.1, R Core Team 2016). To analyse the hierarchical relationships between regional (coarse grain size: 7666 km 2 ) and local (fine grain size: 4 km 2 ) environment as well as fern richness at regional and plot scale, we used structural equation modelling (SEM; Shipley, 2002) of GLMs as implemented in the R-package "piecewiseSEM" (Lefcheck, 2016).

We constructed multiple competing models to test the direction of environmental influences, allowing for coarse-grain size environment to only impact regional richness which in turn impacts plot richness (Figure 2A), or allowing coarse-grain size environment to additionally impact plot richness (Figure 2B).

div.head: INSERT FIGURE 2 AROUND HERE.
div.p: We did not link coarse-grain size and fine-grain size environment because we assume that they are being driven by the same external forces and are not causally connected. Finegrain size environment was tested as predictor of regional richness in model 6 (Figure 2B), but was defined as correlated error of regional richness in all other models to exclude it as a potential correlate. We also tested one model without a direct impact of regional fern richness on plot fern richness for completeness (model 7). To identify the most important environmental predictors for the models, we ran generalised linear models with a Poisson distribution for each response variable against all explanatory factors and evaluated the R-squared-values for each (Table 1). Afterwards, we used principal component analysis (PCA, R package ade4, Dray & Dufour, 2007) to choose from the strongest predictors those that were not strongly correlated.

Even though it had a comparably low R 2 -value, we included habitat homogeneity on a regional, large grain size, as it was shown to be a strong predictor of regional richness in previous studies (Kreft et al., 2010, Table 1). Additionally, we tried to prevent the use of the same predictors at different grain sizes to prevent circularity (except for annual precipitation, which on both grain sizes was found to be extremely important). Since the structural equation models do not test whether the link between regional environment and regional richness exists but rather measures the strengths for the plot richness numbers, we believe that using the same predictors for the regional model as well as in the SEM is not problematic. However, the estimates of these relationships, which demonstrate how strong the predictors were for regional richness at the 83,000 plot localities, are less independent than for local environment and plot richness.
To prevent spatial unbalance in the input plot data, we randomly selected 10 plots from each 10° x 10° grid cell (see Figure 1). When less than 10 plots fell into a cell, all were selected.

Plots with identical GPS-coordinates were considered duplicates and all but one were excluded. This resulted in a final number of roughly 890-1000 plots for each run. This selection as well as the subsequent model testing was repeated 1000 repetition in order to account for differences in species richness of plots in the same grid cell as well as model uncertainty. We corrected for spatial autocorrelation using Moran Eigenvector GLM filtering (MEs, R-package "spdep";

Bivand & Wong, 2018), selecting those Eigenvectors that limit residual autocorrelation below an alpha of 0.05. These MEs were then added as additional variables in the competing SEMs, with links on regional and plot richness. The AIC-values of each model as well as the p-value and number of degrees of freedom of the Fisher's C-test of directed separation, which validates whether all unlinked paths are indeed independent, were extracted for each run, and the best performing model per run was noted. The final best model was the one that performed best most often in AIC and Fischer's C, averaged across all repetitions. Since the strength of the predictors depends strongly on the total range of values, we separated the two paths of the SEM and standardised the predictors to evaluate the models and predictor strengths separately in a later step.

To find the best curve shape describing the relationship between regional and plot richness, we tested a number of different regressions: linear, polynomial (2 nd and 3 rd degree) as well as Michaelis-Menten (R-package "drc", Ritz, Baty, Streibig & Gerhard, 2015) on the same subsampled plot dataset repeated 1000 times. We compared the AIC of the curves to identify the best fit.

div.head: Results
div.p: The predictor testing for the regional fern richness model revealed area size of input entity, elevational range, potential evapotranspiration, mean annual cloud frequency (Wilson & Jetz, 2016), and habitat homogeneity (second order, Tuanmu & Jetz, 2015) as well as aridity index, temperature annual range, annual precipitation, and precipitation of warmest quarter obtained from the Climatologies at high resolution for the earth's land surface areas database (CHELSA; Karger et al., 2017; Table 1) as strongest predictors. The final generalized linear model (Poisson distribution) of regional fern richness on a global extent had an explanatory power of 74.5% (R 2 ) and predictions ranged in species numbers between 0 and 439 at a spatial grain size of 7666 km 2 .

div.head: INSERT FIGURE 3 AROUND HERE.
div.p: For the environmental predictors on the fine grain-size of 4 km 2 , the GLM tests and principal component analyses (PCAs) revealed fine-grain size mean annual temperature, temperature seasonality, temperature annual range as well as mean annual cloud frequency and mean annual precipitation as strong predictors of plot fern richness. The coarse-grain size median of habitat homogeneity, of precipitation of warmest quarter, of annual precipitation, and the elevational range of each 7666 km 2 grid cell were identified as strong predictors of the regional richness at the plot localities.

The comparison of the regression models used to answer Q1 showed the polynomial curve of 3 rd degree to have the best fit in 99.9% of all cases (deltaAIC to next model: 28; Figure 4). The best model showed a gradual increase of plot richness with increasing regional richness up to a regional richness of around 300 species and a mean of plot richness of 23 fern species, with plot richness then decreasing to around 12 species at a regional richness of 440 species.

div.head: INSERT FIGURE 4 AND TABLE 2 AROUND HERE.
div.p: In the structural equation model, the AIC test as well as the X 2 -distributed Fisher's C statistic indicating the goodness-of-fit after tests of directed separation revealed the following order from most to least likely model (Table 2): The model chosen most frequently as the most likely (55.7%) was model 5, in which the coarse-grain size environment directly affects regional as well as plot richness (Q3) and botanical continent affects regional richness (Q2). The second most likely model was model 4 (44.2% chosen, deltaAIC = 19), which also included coarsegrain size environment affecting both regional and plot richness, but did not include an effect of botanical continent. Both models were almost equally often chosen as the most likely. However, the low Fisher's C value for model 4 indicates that a significant path is being missed in the modelincluding this link makes model 4 equal to model 5, supporting model 5 as the most likely again. The third most likely model (model 7, deltaAIC = 38) included effects of coarse-grain size and fine-grain size environment on regional and plot richness, as well as of botanical continent on regional richness. The next most likely model (model 1, deltaAIC = 43) included botanical continent as well as coarse-grain size environment as predictors of regional richness, but without a direct connection between coarse-grain size environment and plot richness, followed by model 6 (deltaAIC = 56), model 2 (deltaAIC = 63), and model 3 (deltaAIC = 111).

div.head: INSERT FIGURE 5 AROUND HERE.
div.p: The most likely model (model 5, Figures 2 and5) revealed that botanical continent had the strongest impact on regional richness (Q2). Comparing continents (Table 3), temperate and tropical Asia were modelled to be more species rich (indicated by positive estimates) compared to Africa, which as the baseline had an estimate of 0. North America and South America had weaker positive estimates, whereas Europe and Australasia had negative estimates when referenced against Africa. The test of directed separation showed that botanical continent did not have a significant effect on plot richness.

Overall, the effect of the predictors on plot richness in the structural equation model was smaller than for regional richness (Figure 5A). However, this depended strongly on the range of the response variables; in the case of plot richness 0-81 species and for regional richness 0-439 species. So, in order to identify the predictor strength independent of the range of the response variable, we standardised each model-path individually. After standardisation (Figure 5b, Table 3), fine-grain size temperature seasonality and temperature annual range were revealed as having the strongest impact on plot fern richness, followed by temperature diurnal range, regional fern richness, annual precipitation, and coarse-grain size cloud frequency. The standardisation also relativised the differences between the strengths of coarse-grain size predictors on regional richness, revealing annual temperature range as the strongest factor.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Using our extensive dataset of almost 83,000 vegetation plots with the regional fern richness model at a resolution of 7666 km 2 , we were able to analyse the determinants and relationships of plot and regional fern richness. In the following, we will focus on the three aspects outlined in our focal questions, namely the relationship of plot and regional richness, the impact of historical or biogeographical factors at different scales and the impact of regional environment on richness at regional and plot scale. Overall, the results of our regional model corresponded with those of Kreft et al. (2010) who used a broadly similar modelling approach, although the higher quantity and quality of the input data and the finer spatial resolution of the model imply that our model has higher explanatory value, as also reflected by the high R 2 values obtained for the model. In essence the model confirms that regional fern richness is highest in wet tropical mountains, in regions of high habitat heterogeneity, and is much lower in Africa compared to other tropical continents.

Focussing on the relationship of regional and local/plot fern richness, surprisingly, plot richness did not show a linear relationship and neither reached a saturation asymptote (Q1), but rather decreased at high levels of regional richness. To our knowledge, such a pattern has not yet been observed or predicted for global patterns of biodiversity of any group of organisms (Srivastava, 1999;Olivares et al., 2018). By showing that this pattern remained stable through 1000 different plot subsets, we can exclude sampling effects as the underlying cause. Additionally, our dataset included 1860 plots from 43 regional polygons with over 250 regional species with most of these plots having been conducted within the scope of fern-oriented studies. It thus seems unlikely that locally super-rich plots were coincidentally missed in super-rich regions. A possible explanation for this unexpected pattern may be that very species-rich regions tend to have a high degree of habitat heterogeneity, which would limit the surface area of each habitat in this region and thus via the species-area relationship the number of locally supported species.

Additionally, regions with high habitat heterogeneity can include habitats that support only few species, such as alpine outcrops or regions with very poor soils. Indeed, the underlying soils are an important factor known to impact fern richness (e.g. Tuomisto et al., 2002) especially at the local scale, but at regional grain sizes, these local differences are harder to detect, leading to high turnover of local species pools that are only small subsamples of the regional species pool, which might be even larger because of the diversity of different soils occurring in a region.

From another point of view, species tend to overlap in their ecological preferences to some degree so that with growing regional richness, locally co-occurring species increasingly compete with each other for the same resources, again leading to higher turnover of species between plots (Karger et al., 2015) or locally dominant species prevent many species from coexisting. Thus, we propose that there may be a regional effect on plot fern community assemblage processes, such as high local species turnover in regionally rich assemblages (Karger et al., 2015). This hypothesis should be tested by targeted sampling. In any case, our data does not support a linear increase of plot richness with regional richness as would be expected if plot richness is simply a subsample of regional richness (e.g. Karger et al., 2011;Bhatta, Grytnes & Vetaas, 2018). Rather, the curve shape suggests that ecological species interactions may limit the number of locally co-occurring fern species at high levels of regional species richness. This effect has indeed been documented for fern assemblages in the Indo-Malayan archipelago, where realized niche widths of species decreased on large islands with large regional species pools (Karger et al., 2014). Kessler, Salazar, Homeier & Kluge (2014) suggest that competitive species exclusions at high levels of individual densities of ferns occur in the Ecuadorian Andes. Such effects may occur more generally, but potentially experimental approaches are needed to unravel the details of the underlying mechanisms.

Considering the influence of inter-continental differences, our analysis confirmed that continents differ in "base levels" of fern species richness, with Africa long known to be the "odd man out" with much lower richness than other tropical continents (Kreft et al., 2010). Indeed, South America and tropical Asia were found to be more species rich when measured against Africa in our analyses. Due to its geological past and history of climate oscillations, tropical Africa is known to have a lower regional richness of ferns (Kreft et al., 2010) but also of many other plant groups (Couvreur, 2015) than found on other tropical continents. However, it has also been established that especially eastern Africa can have high local species diversity as well as high levels of endemism (Couvreur, 2015), which is in agreement with our results that local richness is not defined by the biogeographic past of the region (Q2): Local richness does not appear to be directly influenced by geographical position, but only indirectly via regional richness.

Finally, focussing on the impact of environmental factors, the comparison of different structural equation models revealed that models allowing a direct impact of regional environmental predictors on both regional and plot fern richness were the only ones capturing all paths and thus performing best (Q3): Even though regional environmental predictors shape the number of regionally occurring fern species, they also have a direct impact on the number of locally occurring species in each plot that cannot be substituted with the regional species richness. The most significant coarse-grain size predictor impacting local richness was annual precipitation, followed by precipitation of warmest quarter. Locally, mean annual cloud frequency was the strongest predictor, which especially in higher elevations is related not only to rainfall but also to water input via fog as well as reduced solar irradiance and therefore also actual and potential evapotranspiration. Previous studies found that rainfall is the strongest predictor of regional fern richness (Kreft et al., 2010) and of local fern richness along elevational gradients (Kessler et al., 2011). However, fog can also be of major importance, as shown by the correlation of fern diversity with epiphytic bryophyte cover (Kessler et al., 2011), which is a proxy of air humidity (Karger et al., 2012). The influence of fog on water relations of ferns is presumably two-fold, on the one side via direct water input and on the other via reduced transpiration. Habitat homogeneity and the elevational range within one coarse-grain grid cell only have significant influence on regional richness. Both variables measure differences between habitats within the same grid cell, so that their influence on plot richness is mechanistically limited. Another aspect we could not include in the analyses, but which is likely to act more strongly on plot richness than on regional richness, are the local soil properties. As mentioned above, soils strongly act on local fern richness (Tuomisto et al., 2002), so that differences in soil could lead to different numbers of local richness at otherwise similar regional climatic conditions.

Putting the above considerations into context, our study shows that among the factors considered by us, regional fern richness is primarily driven by climatic factors in combination with strong inter-continental differences that reflect historical influences. Local richness is most strongly impacted by fine-grain size climatic factors, but regional fern richness as well as coarse-grain size environmental factors were also identified through structural equation modelling. Interestingly, we did not find evidence of historical influences acting directly on local richness. Such grain size-dependent differences in factors are commonly invoked in general terms (Hutchinson, 1953;Whittaker, 1977;Ricklefs, 1987;Levin, 1992;Field et al., 2004;Rahbek, 2005), but are still poorly understood for different groups of organisms.
Structural equation modelling as applied here has proven a suitable tool to differentiate between direct and indirect influences of various factors at different spatial resolutions.

Data from the following participating countries (number of plots in parentheses): Austria (177), Belgium (351), Bulgaria (18), Cyprus (16), Czech Republic (47), Denmark (69), Estonia (110), Finland (121), France (6768), Germany (1329), the United Kingdom (390), Greece (15), Hungary (279), Ireland (x12), Italy (766), Latvia (11), Lithuania (18), Luxemburg (112), Netherlands (47), Norway (21), Poland (160), Portugal (58), Romania (37), Russia (147), Serbia (238), Slovenia (64), Slovakia (35), Spain (83), Sweden (166), and Switzerland (755) were included in this study. The collection of ICP Forests data was to a large extent funded by national research institutions and ministries, with support from governmental bodies, services and landowners and the European Commission. Biosketch Anna Weigand is a PhD student in the working group of Michael Kessler. Her research focuses on historical and current processes shaping distribution patterns of ferns.
